questions.question: Which among the following is not a premalignant lesion of vulva?
Which of the following is a common differential diagnosis of verrucuos carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Condyloma acuminata is the common differential diagnosis of verrucous carcinoma.It refers to anogenital warts and has a verrucous appearance.Verrucous carcinoma is a variant of squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. It is locally invasiveand rarely metastasizes.Condyloma lata is a benign and painless cutaneous manifestation of secondary syphilis. It ischaracterized by gray to white lesions, typically located in the oro-genital region.Chancre is a painless genital ulcer most commonly formed during the primary stage of syphilis.

questions.question: A sexually active woman presents with multiple lesions over her genital region as shownbelow. Which of the following organisms are implicated in this condition?820
questions.explanation: The given scenario and image are suggestive of genital warts. Human papillomavirus (HPV) 6 and11 cause nearly all genital warts.It is usually clinically diagnosed but if co-existing neoplasia is suspected then a biopsy is required.HPV serotyping is not required for routine diagnosis.

questions.question: What is the earliest symptom in patients with vulval intraepithelial neoplasia?
questions.explanation: Pruritus is the earliest symptom of VIN as well as vulvar cancer.Clinical features of VIN include:825• Pruritus• White discharge per vagina•• Dyspareunia• Vaginal bleeding

questions.question: A woman with vaginal itching is suspected to have vulval intraepithelial neoplasia. Which ofthe following is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: HPV 16 is the most common cause of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN).Causes of VIN include:• HPV 16, 18, 31, 33• HSV 2• Syphilis•Gonorrhea• Gardnerella vaginalis

questions.question: An elderly woman is diagnosed with vulval intraepithelial neoplasia 3. Which of the followingis false regarding this condition?
questions.explanation: Elderly women with vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) - 3 are HPV negative.VIN 3 is of two types:• Young women - HPV +ve, multiple lesion, 90% regress• Elderly women - HPV-ve, single lesion, associated with lichen sclerosis, often progress toinvasive cancer

questions.question: 821Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecologicalmalignancies?
questions.explanation: Among the given gynecological malignancies, sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is most useful invulval carcinomas.This is because women with earlier stages of vulval cancer can have diseased lymph nodes evenwithout palpable enlargement of nodes. Hence, sentinel lymph node biopsy helps in earlydiagnosis lymph node spread which can be managed by lymph node dissection.A sentinel lymph node is a physiologically, the first lymph node to receive tumor lymphaticdrainage.Malignancies where sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly done are:• Vulval carcinoma• Breast carcinoma826• Penile carcinoma• Malignant melanomaLymphatic mapping is similar technique to SLNB that can also be used in vulval cancers.

questions.question: Which is most common type of vulval cancer?
questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vulval cancer.Other types of vulval cancer include:• Adenocarcinoma• Melanoma• Basal cell carcinomaSarcoma

questions.question: What is the most common type of vaginal cancer likely to be seen in a woman with a historyof intrauterine di-ethyl stilbesterol exposure?
questions.explanation: Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina is commonly seen in adoloscent girls with a history ofintrauterine DES exposure.It involves the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall. Radical hysterectomy, vaginectomy withpelvic lymphadenectomy is the treatment of choice.The most common lesion due to DES exposure is vaginal adenosis and not clear celladenocarcinoma. It is a benign condition.

questions.question: What is the most common site of vulval cancers?
questions.explanation: The most common site of vulval cancer is labia majora > clitoris > labia minora.

questions.question: 822Vulvar carcinoma was diagnosed in a 68-year-old woman who presented with itching andmass over the vulva for 6 months. Sentinel lymph node biopsy revealed positive inguinalnodes. What is the stage of the tumor?
questions.explanation: According to FIGO staging, tumor with positive inguinal lymph node is classified as stage III.

questions.question: In patients with vulval cancer, what is the least common route through which the malignancyspreads?
questions.explanation: Vascular route of spread is rare in vulval cancer. Lymphatic is the most common route of spreadin vulval cancer.827Lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor. The sentinel lymph node biopsy ishelpful for evaluating the spread of vulval cancer. Lymph nodes involved are, superficial inguinalnodes (sentinel node) > deep inguinal nodes > femoral group of nodes.

questions.question: An elderly woman is found to have abnormal cells on a pap smear. Further investigationsreveal vaginal squamous cell carcinoma extending up to the pelvic wall. There is no evidenceof distant metastasis. What is the stage of the tumor in this patient?
questions.explanation: Vaginal cancer extending up to the pelvic wall is stage III.Vaginal cancer commonly affects females >70 years of age. Squamous cell carcinoma is themost common histologic type. It commonly involves the upper third of the posterior wall of thevagina.Patients are mostly asymptomatic. They may present with painless abnormal vaginal bleeding,post-coital bleed, and foul-smelling discharge per vagina.Vaginal cancer staging:••••Stage o Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia-Stage I Carcinoma limited to the vaginal wallStage II - Carcinoma extending beyond the vagina, but not extending to the pelvic wallsStage III - Carcinoma extends up to the pelvic walls-Stage IVA Carcinoma extending beyond the true pelvis/or involving the bladder and/or rectum,or evidence of distant metastasis•Stage IVB - Spread to the distant metastasis

questions.question: A 70-year-old presented with a lesion over the vulva as shown below. Bilateral inguinal lymphnodes were palpable. Biopsy of the lesion revealed cells containing large, pleomorphic nuclei.Which of the following is false regarding this condition?823

options.A: It is the 2nd most common vulval cancer
options.B: The most common site is clitoris
options.C: It may arise from a junctional naevus
options.D: Radical vulvectomy with bilateral regional lymphadenectomy is the preferred treatment

questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of vulval melanoma. The most commonly involved site is labiamajora followed by labia minora and clitoris.Vulval melanoma is the second most common vulval cancer. It may arise from junctional naevus.It has a high propensity for local and distant recurrence and has a poor prognosis.Radical vulvectomy and bilateral regional lymphadenectomy is the preferred treatment.828
